case_name: State of Nagaland v. Members of the 7th Battalion of the Central Reserve Police

facts.text: Appeals filed by State of Nagaland against High Court judgment dated August 26, 1965

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 198 of 1965 and 29-32 of 1966. Appeals from the judgment and order dated August 26, 1965 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court

facts.text: High Court allowed writ petitions and issued writ of mandamus directing Additional Deputy Commissioner, Kohima and State of Nagaland to proceed with trial of respondents

anchor.surface_text: by which the High Court, allowing ,certain writ petitions filed by the respondents, issued a writ of mandamus directing the Additional Deputy Commissioner, Kohima and the State of Nagaland, number to proceed with the trial of the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents are members of 7th Battalion of Central Reserve Police engaged in operations in Nagaland under command of 8th Mountain Division Infantry Brigade

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are members of the 7th Battalion of the Central Reserve Police  shortly called in this judgment the R.P.  who, under the companymand of the 8th.Mountain Division Infantry Brigade, were engaged in operations in the State of Nagaland.

facts.text: On or about August 3, 1964, seven hostile Nagas captured and kept as prisoners at Pfutser Camp were murdered and bodies secretly disposed of

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of information that on or about August 3, 1964, seven hostile Nagas, who were captured and kept prisoners with the C.R.P. at Pfutser Camp, were murdered and their dead bodies secretly disposed of,

facts.text: Police arrested 44 persons and charged them with offences under sections 302/109/34 and 201 IPC

anchor.surface_text: the police, after investigating the report, arrested 44 persons and charged them with offences under ss. 302/109/34 and 201, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Some other CRPF members charged under section 436 IPC for setting fire to houses in certain villages

anchor.surface_text: Some other members of the C.R.P. were charged at the same time under s. 436, Indian Penal Code for setting fire to some houses in certain villages.

facts.text: Trial to take place before Additional Deputy Commissioner, Kohima

anchor.surface_text: The trial was about to take place before the Additional Deputy Com- missioner, Kohima, when an objection was taken

facts.text: Objection raised that trial should be before Court of Session after committal as offences triable exclusively by Sessions Court under CrPC

anchor.surface_text: when an objection was taken that the trial should be before the Court of Session after companymitment, as the offences were triable by the Court of Session exclusively, under the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Additional Deputy Commissioner overruled objection stating no Courts of Session in Naga Hills District and CrPC not in force

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Deputy Commissioner overruled the objection pointing out that there were numberCourts of Session in the Naga Hills District and the Criminal Procedure Code was also number in force.

facts.text: Procedure to follow Rules for Administration of Justice and Police in Naga Hills District, 1937

anchor.surface_text: He ruled that companymittal proceedings and trial before a Sessions Court were, therefore, number possible and the procedure laid down in the Rules for the Administration of Justice and Police in the Naga Hills District, 1937,

facts.text: Respondents filed five petitions under Art. 226 to quash proceedings under Rules of 1937

anchor.surface_text: The respondents filed five petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution for writs or orders to quash the proceedings under the Rules of 1937 and other reliefs.

facts.text: High Court quashed proceedings and directed trial under Rules of 1937 not to proceed

anchor.surface_text: By the order impugned here a Divisional Bench companysisting of C. Sanjeeva Rao Nayudu and S. K. Dutta JJ., quashed the proceedings and issued a writ of mandamus directing the Additional Deputy Commissioner and the State of Nagaland number to proceed under the Rules of 1937

facts.text: State of Nagaland formed in 1962 comprising Naga Hills-Tuensang Area

anchor.surface_text: The State of Nagaland was formed by the State of Nagaland Act, 1962  27 of 1962 . That Act repealed and replaced the Nagaland  Transitional Provisions  Regulation, 1961  Regulation 2 of 1961 . The territory of the new State companyprises the Naga Hills-Tuensang Area

facts.text: Rules for Administration of Justice and Police in Naga Hills District made in 1937 by Governor of Assam under Scheduled Districts Act, 1874

anchor.surface_text: On March 25, 1937, On that day the Governor of Assam prescribed revised Rules under the powers vested in him by s. 6 of the Scheduled Districts Act.

facts.text: Criminal Procedure Code not in force in Naga Hills District

anchor.surface_text: there were numberCourts of Session in the Naga Hills District and the Criminal Procedure Code was also number in force.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeals and sets aside High Court order, directs trial under Rules of 1937

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeals and set aside the order of the High Court. The trial of the respondents shall proceed under the Rules of 1937.

facts.text: Naga Hills District administered specially for over a century with ordinary laws not applied

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with a new State formed as late as 1962 but the territory of this State has had a very long and chequered history. The area, where the trial is taking place is one of the backward tracts and it has, for a century and more, been specially administered.

facts.text: Scheduled Districts Act, 1874 repealed by Adaptation of Laws Order, 1937

anchor.surface_text: After this the Scheduled Districts Act became obsolete and war, repealed by the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1937.

facts.text: Rules of 1937 continued in force by saving clause in Adaptation of Laws Order

anchor.surface_text: The Rules of 1937 were enacted by numberification and if numberifications were saved the Rules in the numberification were also saved.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules of 1937 were designed for an extremely simple and unsophisticated society and approximate to the rules of natural justice.

holdings.text: The Rules of 1937 survived the repeal of the Scheduled Districts Act by the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1937, due to the saving clause preserving notifications under which they were made.

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that the Rules of 1937 did not survive the repeal of the Scheduled Districts Act, 1874 by the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1937, notwithstanding the saving clause in the Adaptation of Laws Order. This argument is based on the submission that the savings clause reproduced earlier by us did not mention rules as such. We do not agree. The saving clause preserved all notifications. The Rules of 1937 were enacted by notification and if notifications were saved the Rules in the notification were also saved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Saving clause explicitly preserves notifications; Rules made by notification hence saved; successively preserved by later statutes including Art. 372.

holdings.text: Sections 6 and 7 of the Scheduled Districts Act conferred power on local government to regulate judicial procedure of officers administering justice, not merely administrative instructions.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this is a wrong reading of the section. We must not forget that the Scheduled Districts Act was passed because the backward tracts were never brought within the operation of all the general Acts and Regulations particularly the Criminal Procedure Code and were removed from the operation and jurisdiction of the ordinary courts of Judicature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation considering historical context of backward tracts excluded from CrPC; Governor-General's own rules confirm judicial scope; succession of similar rules.

holdings.text: The Scheduled Districts Act did not involve excessive delegation of legislative power as preamble and s.6 provided policy guidance for regulating procedure in backward tracts.

anchor.surface_text: It is next contended that the Act itself was bad because the Legislature did not legislate on the subject of judicial procedure but left essential legislation to a delegate, without laying down any or at least enough guidance in the Scheduled Districts Act for those who were to make Rules under it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble indicates policy for backward areas; s.6 guides appointment and procedure; prior rules (1874) as model; not unguided per precedents like Harishankar Bagla.

holdings.text: Section 7 of Scheduled Districts Act conferred concurrent power on local government to amend rules made by Governor-General in Council.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase 'as the case may be' indicates equal authority; Bengal Assam Laws Act 1905 supports; historical practice of successive rules.

holdings.text: Rules of 1937 qualify as 'procedure established by law' under Article 21; provision to follow 'spirit' of CrPC is valid law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Spirit over letter suits simple society, approximates natural justice; discretion controlled by substance, not arbitrary; precedent in Gurumayum case.

holdings.text: Rules of 1937 do not violate Article 14; different procedures for backward tracts justified by exigencies, no discrimination.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Regional differences permissible if reasonably classified; backward tracts' conditions warrant simplicity; no intra-state discrim (CrPC nowhere applies); elastic rules reduce arbitrariness.

holdings.text: 'Spirit of the Code of Criminal Procedure' constitutes valid procedure under Rules of 1937, applied correctly in warrant procedure here.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent explains spirit avoids technicalities for unsophisticated; warrant procedure followed here appropriate sans Sessions Court.

holdings.text: Rules of 1937 were validly enacted, continue in force, not void under Arts. 14 or 21; CrPC excluded; trial proceeds under Rules of 1937.

anchor.surface_text: Whether such rules particularly the Rules of 1937 were validly enacted, whether they continue to be in force and whether they are rendered void by reason of Arts. 14 and 21 of the Constitution are the main problems requiring consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings on enactment (ss.6/7), continuance (savings/Art.372), constitutionality (Arts.14/21); historical continuity.

holdings.text: Rules of 1937 continue in force post various constitutional changes including State of Nagaland Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether such rules particularly the Rules of 1937 were validly enacted, whether they continue to be in force and whether they are rendered void by reason of Arts. 14 and 21 of the Constitution are the main problems requiring consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Saved by Adaptation Order, GOI Act ss.292/293, Independence Act, Art.372; Nagaland Act s.26 continues existing laws.

holdings.text: Rules of 1937 not rendered void by Arts. 14 and 21.

anchor.surface_text: Whether such rules particularly the Rules of 1937 were validly enacted, whether they continue to be in force and whether they are rendered void by reason of Arts. 14 and 21 of the Constitution are the main problems requiring consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.21: valid law/procedure; Art.14: no discrim, justified classification; natural justice approximated.

holdings.text: Code of Criminal Procedure does not apply in Naga Hills/Nagaland; trial under Rules of 1937 governs.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Deputy Commissioner overruled the objection pointing out that there were no Courts of Session in the Naga Hills District and the Criminal Procedure Code was also not in force... We accordingly hold that the Rules of 1937 continue to be in force and govern the trial of these respondents. The Code of Criminal Procedure admittedly does not apply there

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historically excluded; Rules provide substitute; no Sessions infrastructure.

holdings.text: Appeals allowed; High Court order set aside; trial of respondents to proceed under Rules of 1937 before Additional Deputy Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeals and set aside the order of the High Court. The trial of the respondents shall proceed under the Rules of 1937.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in quashing proceedings; Rules valid and applicable.

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that the Rules of 1937 did not survive the repeal of the Scheduled Districts Act, 1874 by the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1937, notwithstanding the saving clause in the Adaptation of Laws Order. This argument is based on the submission that the savings clause reproduced earlier by us did not mention rules as such. We do not agree. The saving clause preserved all notifications. The Rules of 1937 were enacted by notification and if notifications were saved the Rules in the notification were also saved.

We accordingly allow the appeals and set aside the order of the High Court. The trial of the respondents shall proceed under the Rules of 1937. We may, however, say that it would be better if, as soon as it is found to be expedient, all Rules are cancelled and one uniform set of Rules is made for the whole of this area.
recting the Additional Deputy Commissioner and the State of Nagaland number to proceed under the Rules of 1937 with the trial of the accused before hi

edges.explanation: Holding h10 explicitly states Rules of 1937 not rendered void by Arts. 14 and 21, directly addressing issue i3.

anchor.surface_text: Whether such rules particularly the Rules of 1937 were validly enacted, whether they continue to be in force and whether they are rendered void by reason of Arts. 14 and 21 of the Constitution are the main problems requiring consideration.

We accordingly allow the appeals and set aside the order of the High Court. The trial of the respondents shall proceed under the Rules of 1937. We may, however, say that it would be better if, as soon as it is found to be expedient, all Rules are cancelled and one uniform set of Rules is made for the whole of this area.

We accordingly allow the appeals and set aside the order of the High Court. The trial of the respondents shall proceed under the Rules of 1937. anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this is a wrong reading of the section. We must not forget that the Scheduled Districts Act was passed because the backward tracts were never brought within the operation of all the general Acts and Regulations particularly the Criminal Procedure Code and were removed from the operation and jurisdiction of the ordinary courts of Judicature.

We accordingly allow the appeals and set aside the order of the High Court. The trial of the respondents shall proceed under the Rules of 1937. We may, however, say that it would be better if, as soon as it is found to be expedient, all Rules are cancelled and one uniform set of Rules is made for the whole of this area.

anchor.surface_text: It is next contended that the Act itself was bad because the Legislature did not legislate on the subject of judicial procedure but left essential legislation to a delegate, without laying down any or at least enough guidance in the Scheduled Districts Act for those who were to make Rules under it.

We accordingly allow the appeals and set aside the order of the High Court. The trial of the respondents shall proceed under the Rules of 1937. We may, however, say that it would be better if, as soon as it is found to be expedient, all Rules are cancelled and one uniform set of Rules is made for the whole of this area.
